responses: Make sure Wi-Fi is turned on. Go to Settings > Network & Internet > Wi-Fi, then ensure it's enabled. Restart your modem and router if needed.

responses: Ensure no other devices are consuming too much bandwidth. Also, check for physical obstructions between your device and the Wi-Fi router.

responses: Ensure the Ethernet cable is properly connected to both your PC and the router. Try switching to a different cable if possible.

If the Ethernet connection stopped working after an update, you can roll back the update by going to Settings > Windows Update > Update History.

responses: To reset network settings, go to Settings > Network & Internet > Advanced Network Settings > Network Reset. This will remove all network adapters and reinstall them.
After a network reset, you'll need to reconnect to your Wi-Fi network and reconfigure any VPNs or custom network settings.
Network reset can help solve problems after an upgrade or when you can't connect to shared drives.

Resetting your router restores it to its default settings, which may resolve connection problems caused by incorrect configurations.
